content:
Thanks to all your help with some questions of mine, I may be ready to prove a theorem. I'd be happy for feedback.

First a definition:

Definition. A softened preorder is a category such that given f,g ⁣:x→yf, g \colon x \to yf,g:x→y, there exists an automorphism α ⁣:y→y\alpha \colon y \to yα:y→y such that g=αfg = \alpha fg=αf.

The idea is that if we can always take α=1y\alpha = 1_yα=1y​ then our category is a preorder, but in general we are weakening or 'softening' the condition that there's at most one morphism from any object xxx to any object yyy. Note that the roles of xxx and yyy are really symmetrical here, since f=α−1gf = \alpha^{-1} gf=α−1g.

Exercise. The opposite of a softened preorder may not be a softened preorder, but it is always an opsoftened preorder: given f,g ⁣:x→yf, g \colon x \to yf,g:x→y, there exists an automorphism α ⁣:x→x\alpha \colon x \to xα:x→x such that g=fαg = f \alphag=fα.

I'm happy to hear suggestions for better names for these kind of categories - and I know category theorists like nothing more than arguing about terminology, so consider this opportunity to argue my big gift to all of you. But I want to move on here....

Theorem. Suppose PPP is a preorder, F:P→GpdF: P \to \mathbf{Gpd}F:P→Gpd is a pseudofunctor, and C=∫FC = \int FC=∫F is the category built via the covariant Grothendieck construction from FFF. Then CCC is a softened preorder. Conversely if CCC is a softened preorder then C≃∫FC \simeq \int FC≃∫F for some preorder PPP and pseudofunctor F:P→GpdF: P \to \mathbf{Gpd}F:P→Gpd.

Let me prove the first part now and try to prove the converse later.

To reduce the hassle I will assume FFF is a functor, not a pseudofunctor; I believe the pseudofunctor case works similarly.

Proof of forwards direction when FFF is a functor. Suppose PPP is a preorder, F:P→GpdF: P \to \mathbf{Gpd}F:P→Gpd is a functor, and C=∫FC = \int FC=∫F is the category built via the covariant Grothendieck construction from FFF.

An object x∈∫Fx \in \int Fx∈∫F is a pair consisting of an object x0∈Cx_0 \in Cx0​∈C together with an object x1∈F(x0)x_1 \in F(x_0)x1​∈F(x0​). Similarly y∈∫Fy \in \int Fy∈∫F is a pair (y0,y1)(y_0, y_1)(y0​,y1​) where y1∈F(y0)y_1 \in F(y_0)y1​∈F(y0​).

A morphism f:x→yf: x \to yf:x→y in ∫F\int F∫F is then a morphism f0:x0→y0f_0: x_0 \to y_0f0​:x0​→y0​ in PPP (of which there's at most one) together with a morphism f1:F(f0)(x1)→y1f_1 : F(f_0)(x_1) \to y_1f1​:F(f0​)(x1​)→y1​.

Suppose we have another morphism g:x→yg: x \to yg:x→y. This is a morphism g0:x0→y0g_0: x_0 \to y_0g0​:x0​→y0​ together with a morphism g1:F(g0)(x1)→y1g_1 : F(g_0)(x_1) \to y_1g1​:F(g0​)(x1​)→y1​.

But because PPP is a preorder, f0=g0f_0 = g_0f0​=g0​, so g1:F(f0)(x1)→y0g_1: F(f_0)(x_1) \to y_0g1​:F(f0​)(x1​)→y0​.

Note that f1:F(f0)(x1)→y1f_1 : F(f_0)(x_1) \to y_1f1​:F(f0​)(x1​)→y1​ and g1:F(f0)(x1)→y1g_1: F(f_0)(x_1) \to y_1g1​:F(f0​)(x1​)→y1​ are morphisms with the same source and same target in the groupoid F(y0)F(y_0)F(y0​). We thus have

g1=(g1f1−1)f1 g_1 = (g_1 f_1^{-1}) f_1 g1​=(g1​f1−1​)f1​

I now claim that

g=αf g = \alpha f g=αf

for some morphism α:y→y\alpha : y \to yα:y→y in ∫F\int F∫F. This morphism α\alphaα should itself be a pair of a morphism α0 ⁣:y0→y0\alpha_0 \colon y_0 \to y_0α0​:y0​→y0​ and a morphism α1 ⁣:F(α0)(y1)→y1\alpha_1 \colon F(\alpha_0)(y_1) \to y_1 α1​:F(α0​)(y1​)→y1​. Let's take α0=1\alpha_0 = 1α0​=1, so we need α1 ⁣:y1→y1\alpha_1 \colon y_1 \to y_1 α1​:y1​→y1​. And let's take

α1=g1f1−1 ⁣:y1→y1\alpha_1 = g_1 f_1^{-1} \colon y_1 \to y_1α1​=g1​f1−1​:y1​→y1​

So, we're taking α=(1,g1f1−1)\alpha = (1, g_1 f_1^{-1})α=(1,g1​f1−1​) and I claim

g=αf g = \alpha f g=αf

Everything here is a pair, and we're saying

(g0,g1)=(1,g1f1−1)∘(f0,f1)(g_0, g_1) = (1, g_1 f_1^{-1}) \circ (f_0, f_1) (g0​,g1​)=(1,g1​f1−1​)∘(f0​,f1​)

Composition at right is taking place in the Grothendieck construction ∫F\int F∫F. Thus, the first component of each pair composes in the usual way in PPP, and for this we're claiming

g0=f0g_0 = f_0g0​=f0​

which we've seen is true because PPP is a preorder. The second component composes in a more fancy way, and for this we're claiming

g1=(g1f1−1)∘F(α1)(f1) g_1 = (g_1 f_1^{-1}) \circ F(\alpha_1)(f_1) g1​=(g1​f1−1​)∘F(α1​)(f1​)

which is true because α1=1\alpha_1 = 1α1​=1 and FFF is a functor so F(α1)(f1)=f1F(\alpha_1)(f_1) = f_1F(α1​)(f1​)=f1​. \qquad ▮

I don't think every softened preorder arises in this way? For any pair of softened preorders C,DC,DC,D, the cograph of the terminal profunctor from CCC to DDD seems to be a softened preorder. But if C,DC,DC,D are BZB\mathbb ZBZ (or some other connected non-trivial groupoid) then the terminal profunctor isn't representable so the cograph shouldn't come from the Grothendieck construction. Maybe if you assume the automorphism α\alphaα is unique in the definition of softened preorder.

If the automorphism is assumed unique, then xxx is called prequasi-initial in Tholen's MacNeille completion of concrete categories with local properties. If xxx is also weakly initial, then it is called quasi-initial. There are probably other concepts relevant to what you are studying in this paper.

David Wärn said:

I don't think every softened preorder arises in this way?

Indeed, I think you're right. Is the following a counterexample? The category with only two objects x,yx,yx,y, a single morphism f:x→yf: x \to yf:x→y, the identity morphism 1x:x→x1_x : x \to x1x​:x→x, and two automorphisms 1y,α:y→y1_y, \alpha: y \to y1y​,α:y→y. (This forces αf=f\alpha f = fαf=f and α2=1y\alpha^2 = 1_yα2=1y​.)

So, I no longer have hopes for the converse here:

Theorem. Suppose PPP is a preorder, F:P→GpdF: P \to \mathbf{Gpd}F:P→Gpd is a pseudofunctor, and C=∫FC = \int FC=∫F is the category built via the covariant Grothendieck construction from FFF. Then CCC is a softened preorder. Conversely if CCC is a softened preorder then C≃∫FC \simeq \int FC≃∫F for some preorder PPP and pseudofunctor F:P→GpdF: P \to \mathbf{Gpd}F:P→Gpd.

By the way, I was trying to prove that the category of central finite-dimensional simple algebras over a field kkk is a softened preorder. (Here AAA is central if the center of AAA is kkk.) This example is the only reason why I care about this topic.

I discovered to my delight that this result is true, and it follows right away from the Skolem-Noether theorem.

(I hadn't expected it to be a new result, so I'm not disappointed: I'm just happy that it was discovered by two bigshots.)

It was useful seeing your thought process and how you asked for help in connection with the grothendieck construction, thank you for threading me in. You ended up with a nice example of how a condition on the domain of the pseudofunctor translates to a condition on the opfibration.

Thanks! The good thing about doing math in public is that people can help out, and also people can watch and maybe learn something or at least enjoy watching someone flounder around and make mistakes.

I'm not quite done yet because I haven't gotten a "structure theorem" that describes all softened preorders. From my counterexamples so far, I'm guessing every softened preorder is a "quotient" of one obtained by the Grothendieck construction. There may be an adjunction between the 2-category of softened preorders and the 2-category of preorders equipped with pseudofunctors to Gpd\mathsf{Gpd}Gpd.

However, instead of investigating this general idea further right now, I think I'll turn toward the examples I'm actually interested in, and come back to this if it turns out to help.
